title: How do rabbits in Watership Down view hares? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hares are a completely different species than rabbits. Any interaction between the two would be that of caution. As the Wikipedia page for the European Hare in states: Hares “seem to be fewer in number in areas with high rabbit populations, although there appears to be little interaction between the two species and no aggression.” It may seem like General Woundwort is a good candidate to be a hare – he is described as “very wild,” “savage,” “terrifying to fight,” and he is known to have a lot more weight than that of an average rabbit – However I’m convinced he is not. On one hand Adams describes his parents: his mother a doe, and his father “a happy-go-lucky, restless buck.” He also refers to Woundwort as a rabbit multiple times throughout the book: “a singular rabbit,” and “most rabbits in his situation would…” It is interesting to note that Adams directly compares Woundwort to, but does not claim him to be, “Cowper’s Hare,” which is a reference to William Cowper’s “Epitaph on a Hare.” But to answer the question, because real rabbits do not have any special interactions with hares, Watership Down ones wouldn’t either. It’s possible upon meeting one they might try to be diplomatic like they did with the mouse, or even the seagull, Keehar, but only with a purpose in mind. For fun, here are the second and third stanza of Cowper’s “Epitaph on a Hare”: “Old Tiney, surliest of his kind, Who, nursed with tender care, And to domesticate bounds confined, Was still a wild jack-hare. Though duly from my hand he took His pittance every night, He did it with a jealous look, And, when he could, would bite.”
